column2: Task Title
column3: Task Description 1
column4: Task Description 2

column2: Access market guides
column3: We have over 100 market guides to help you find the information you need on your target export market. Filter by sector to see the markets best suited to your product or service.
column4: See the latest market data, sector-specific information and details of any trade agreements that are in place with that chosen market. Find details on how to do business, including tax rates and import regulations.

column2: Explore markets of interest
column3: With our Where to Export service you can find trade data specific to the goods you're exporting and the markets you want to export to.
column4: You will need to sign up to great.gov.uk to use this service. Once signed in, find your product using the product look up and choose the markets you'd like to research. You can then compare the markets side by side to see which is best suited to your business.

column2: Assess the most suitable markets
column3: Use our market guides to assess which country could be most suitable for your products or service, or to find out how to take advantage of a new export opportunity.
column4: See the latest market data, sector-specific information and details of any trade agreements that are in place with that chosen market. Find details on how to do business, including tax rates and import regulations.

column2: Understand market research
column3: Researching potential overseas markets is the foundation of any export plan. From starting your research online to visiting the market, find out how best to approach this essential first step.
column4: Understanding the competition, local market conditions and customer demand will give you clear insights into the suitability of a market. You'll also need to know if there are any adaptations needed to your product or service for it to be successful.

column2: Understand cultural and language adaptations
column3: Adapting your product or service to suit the culture and tastes of local customers is sometimes necessary if you want to successfully launch in a new export market.
column4: Research your target market as thoroughly as possible. See what other companies offer and how they've adapted their products and look at what is produced locally.  And if possible, visit the market to get a real feel for what customers are looking for.

column2: Plan a market visit
column3: One of the best ways to know if a potential market is right for your business is to visit it in person. But to get the most out of your visit, you should have a solid plan in place.
column4: Preparation means more than general background research. You'll need a clear itinerary for your visit, with contacts lined up to speak to. Set up meetings with potential buyers and intermediaries before you go. And take time to find out everything you can about the competition.

column2: Identify opportunities in a selected market
column3: Search our database of thousands of live sales leads and pitch your business to overseas buyers looking for products and services like yours.
column4: Enter your product or service and choose your target market or region. Apply through an expression of interest or get in contact with the buyer directly using the contact details, where provided.

column2: Find networks and contacts in a market
column3: We cannot currently provide a list of potential contacts in your chosen export market. Contact your trade association or chamber of commerce for help on finding the right contacts for your business.

column2: Understand how to develop overseas networks
column3: Once you've successfully entered a new export market, you'll want to turn your attention to growing your market share.
column4: Your growth strategy will vary depending on your product, service and the local market conditions. Research is key, and a good place to start is to talk to businesses already trading in the market to see how they have achieved their growth goals.

column2: Connect with international buyers
column3: Use our service to create a business profile on great.gov.uk and connect with international buyers from across the globe.
column4: By registering your business, you'll give companies looking to buy from your industry an easy way to find you. You can highlight your company's projects and experience to give buyers insight into what you do and attract more business by connecting with the right international buyers.

column2: Identify relevant events for my business
column3: Industry events are one of the most effective ways to support companies looking for new trade opportunities in overseas markets.
column4: The Department for Business and Trade's calendar of events is updated regularly with both UK and overseas events, as well as overseas missions.  You can also join the UK Export Academy for a free calendar of live webinars covering everything from the essentials of exporting through to market and sector specific sessions.

column2: Register for an event
column3: To register for an event, find the event or trade mission you are interested in, read the event details and click the link to register your interest.
column4: The Department for Business and Trade's calendar of events is updated regularly with both UK and overseas events, as well as overseas missions.  You can also join the UK Export Academy for a free calendar of live webinars covering everything from the essentials of exporting through to market and sector specific sessions.

column2: Prepare for a market research trip or trade mission
column3: A trade mission is an organised visit to a country or region by a group of companies, usually set up by a government department, trade federation or similar organisation.
column4: Most missions are a busy and varied programme of meetings, site visits, and networking socials with various local organisations. These can range from local businesses, distributors, and professional services to government departments, regional trade bodies and local consular staff.

column2: Explore ways to get goods or services to market
column3: From direct sales to using a distributor and from e-commerce to setting up a business overseas, there are many ways you can get your products or services into a target export market.
column4: The most successful route into a market is the one which best suits your product, the country you're selling to, and most importantly, the customers in that market. But your appetite for growth and the stage your business is at may also be a factor.

column2: Understand how to work with a partner in market
column3: For many goods and services, the best way to enter a new market is through a partnership. This can be an agent or distributor, wholesaler, retailer or franchisee.
column4: The type of partner you choose depends on the goods or services you're selling, and the business culture of your target market. In-market partners will have a good understanding of the local market conditions and trends, and how best to position your brand against the competition.

column2: Find a partner in market
column3: We cannot currently provide a list of potential in-market partners in your chosen export market. Contact your trade association or chamber of commerce for help on finding the right partner for your business.

column2: Understand how to find a distributor in a market
column3: Distributors buy your products from you, usually at a discounted price, and sell them on in the marketplace. They'll hold stock locally and handle all logistics.
column4: Working with a distributor is one of the most common ways to enter a market for goods exporters. They are a good option if you're looking to reduce the risk of entering a new market, but you will also lose some control over how your products are sold.

column2: Find a distributor in a market
column3: We cannot currently provide a list of potential distributors in your chosen export market. Contact your trade association or chamber of commerce for help on finding the right distributor for your business.

column2: Understand how to find an agent when exporting
column3: Agents sell your products on your behalf. They don't hold any of your stock and transactions are made between your business and the end user.
column4: The main role of an agent is to generate sales, earning a commission as they do. They generally have good local knowledge and can be a simple and low-cost introduction to a new market. However, they are not suitable for all products or services.

column2: Find an agent in a market
column3: We cannot currently provide a list of potential agents in your chosen export market. Contact your trade association or chamber of commerce for help on finding the right agent for your business.

column2: Understand how to use ecommerce to expand overseas
column3: Selling online is one of the easier routes to market for new exporters, with less investment than some more traditional methods. Most businesses usually use a combination of digital channels to achieve the furthest reach.
column4:
As well as business-to-consumer websites and online marketplaces, business-to-business ecommerce is also increasingly popular. Major companies, governments, schools and hospitals often procure their goods and services online.  

But there can be costs involved in selling online overseas, including translation, currency conversion and hiring digital experts to help run the operation

column2: Understand how to sell direct to your customer
column3: Direct export sales involve contacting and selling to an overseas customer without using an intermediary, like a distributor. It can be lower-risk, but also requires time and effort to develop.
column4:
A good website and social media presence may get potential customers contacting you, but often you will need to reach out into the market to find them. 

You should know or be able to easily identify your potential customers, their problems or needs and be able to influence them to buy your product.

column2: Understand how to use licencing to sell overseas
column3: Licensing means giving a third party the right to make and sell your product, service, or intellectual property (IP) in a particular market, in return for a payment.
column4:
If you're a new business, it is usually not recommended to start selling with a licensing model. If you rely on your brand story to sell, you may not want to give up control before you're well established. 

But in some instances, licensing can be a cost-effective way to expand into a new market quickly without having to sell to customers directly.

column2: Understand local business culture
column3: Business practices can vary widely across export markets. There's a much greater chance of a business deal being successful if you've built credibility by taking the time to understand the local culture.
column4: Use your network and talk to people who have worked in the market. If the business culture is relationship based, your customers may want to get to know you before doing a deal. But if it's transactional, be prepared to get right down to business.

column2: Manage bribery and corruption overseas
column3: Corrupt behaviour is often hard to spot, especially when you're operating in an unfamiliar culture. Before you do business with another organisation, it's important to carry out background checks.
column4:
When doing business, pay close attention if the people you're dealing with try to rush through any business without allowing for due diligence or provide very little paperwork.

Ask yourself ' does this seem appropriate or proportional? Does it make sense, and would you carry on doing business if this was happening back in the UK?

column2: Understand payment terms
column3: Payment terms are agreements which ensure you get paid the right amount by your buyers, at a time that's right for you. Well-constructed payment terms are your first safeguard against non-payment.
column4: Consumer sales are usually paid at the point of sale. But with business sales it can be more complex. The terms you agree with your buyers depend on several factors, including how much business you're negotiating and the level of non-payment risk in your export market.

column2: Ensure you get paid
column3: Different countries have different regulations and laws around payments. You may find your preferred method of payment won't be possible, so do your research before you start exporting.
column4: You can negotiate payment terms to reduce the risk of non-payment ' for example, getting buyers to pay in advance if they're new to you. For larger payments or where you need more security, there are financial products provided by banks, such as letters of credit, which can reduce or remove risk.

column2: Setting up an overseas business entity
column3: The first step in setting up a business in your target market is to do your research. Talk to other businesses already present and get legal and financial advice from local lawyers and accountants.
column4: Some markets are more straightforward than others when it comes to setting up a business. But you may not be able to simply replicate your domestic business model. You need to make sure you know about local business rules and regulations, employment laws and know how easy it is to recruit staff.

column2: Sending UK staff to work abroad
column3: When sending staff to work abroad it's important you understand the rules around tax and National Insurance. How you calculate PAYE and NI depends on where they're working and how long you expect them to be working there.
column4: Employees who spend most of their time abroad over a period of a year or more may be able to obtain full UK tax relief on their earnings. If your employee is on an overseas contract, it's possible that the tax authorities in the overseas country will want to make tax deductions from your employee's income.

column2: Setting up a joint venture
column3: A joint venture (JV) is a business partnership between 2 or more companies that enables the partners to work together towards a specific business goal.
column4: A joint venture with an overseas company can be a quick and cost-effective route into a new market. It's a great way to access regional knowledge, gain insights into local regulations and reduce risk to your business. But they can be complex, so make sure you have experienced legal and trading advice from the outset.

column2: Setting up a franchise overseas
column3: A franchise is a business arrangement where you allow another person or business to copy your business name and processes and sell goods or services to specifications set by you.
column4: Make sure your franchise is attractive and create a pitch document to sell your franchise. Make sure your intellectual property, particularly your trademark, is protected in the target market. This should be done as early as possible and certainly before you enter into any business discussions.

column2: Understand what may class as Intellectual Property
column3: Intellectual property is often a company's most important and valued intangible asset. Patents, trademarks, design rights and copyrights can all be protected under IP laws.
column4: Protecting your IP should be a fundamental part of your exporting strategy. Even if you've protected yourself in the UK, you're not automatically protected in other countries abroad.  In most countries, the 'first to file' system exists, so act early before someone else does.

column2: Understand local market IP laws
column3: To protect your intellectual property when trading overseas or selling online to overseas customers, you usually need to apply for protection in each country you are trading in.
column4:
Protecting and managing IP abroad can be very complex. You may want to file separate applications in individual countries or make use of an international process which allows you to file in several countries at once. 

Either way, you should always seek help from an IP attorney or other professional IP advisor.

column2: Identify IP protection organisations
column3: The organisation you need to contact for help protecting your IP overseas depends on the type of IP you want to protect and which market you are trading in.
column4: The Intellectual Property Office has several country and region-specific guides to help you protect and manage your intellectual property in overseas markets. Giving you advice and guidance on what to do and who to contact in your target market.

column2: Contact the UK overseas intellectual property attach' network
column3: Find contact details for IP liaison officers in Europe, Southeast Asia, China, Latin America, North America, Gulf States and India.
column4: The UK overseas intellectual property attach' network works with local DBT and FCDO colleagues to provide support for UK businesses seeking advice on local IP matters.

column2: Using the UK overseas intellectual property attache network
column3: The UK overseas intellectual property attach' network works with local DBT and FCDO colleagues to provide support for UK businesses seeking advice on local IP matters.
column4: The IP liaison officers also help to raise awareness of IP through business outreach. This includes briefing business delegations and liaising with host governments and stakeholders about local and international IP frameworks.

column2: Get help responding to a request for a quotation
column3: Pitching your business, or responding to a tender, in an overseas market are common ways to generate new business. But the challenges you may face are different to those in the UK.
column4: If you don't speak the language you may need to use a local partner to communicate your offer. You can improve your chances of success by speaking with other UK companies who work with your potential buyer. Similarly, trade associations in your sector may be able to offer you advice.

column2: Negotiating a price for exports
column3: You may need to negotiate on price when pitching for new business ' especially if you're selling your product through distribution partners, or as part of a tender process.
column4: How long this takes depends on many factors, such as the complexity of your market, who you're selling to, volume of sales, and how negotiations are handled culturally in your target market. To understand how negotiations take place in your new market, work with local partners who have experience of doing business in the region.

column2: Understand how to conduct due dilligence
column3: Due diligence is a common business process where you perform a detailed review of a potential customer or client before you start doing business with them.
column4: Due diligence doesn't just mean pages of detailed documentation. It can also mean simply asking the right questions at the right time, keeping your eyes open to things that feel irregular, and getting the right advice if something doesn't feel quite right.

column2: Get legal advice
column3: The Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO) provides lists of English-speaking lawyers abroad to help British nationals find the legal support they need.
column4: You can use this service to find legal representation by country or a more specific location, or by a particular area of legal expertise, such as IP law, property law or tax. All lawyers on the lists have confirmed they can provide services in English.

column2: Drafting a contract for export sales
column3: It's important to draft a contract as soon as you've found a potential buyer for your product to make sure you have complete clarity on everything you agree.
column4: Every contract will be different and dependent on what you agree with the buyer. Seek international legal support to help you with any contract, both in the UK and within your chosen market ' they will have expert knowledge of local laws and key contract considerations.

column2: Understand professional qualification recognition
column3: The recognition of professional qualifications is a system which allows professionals qualified in one country to practice in another, without having to requalify.
column4: To support mutual recognition with EU and international partners, the UK government encourages regulatory and professional bodies to enter into arrangements which enable the recognition of professional qualifications between the UK and existing or potential international trade partners.

column2: Check ways to get funding
column3: There are many ways you can finance or fund your export business. The way that's right for you depends on the size and stage of your business.
column4: Generally, you can borrow money (bank loans, finance platforms) or get someone to invest in your business (equity partnerships). Each method has its pros and cons and there is no universally correct option.

column2: Find export funding opportunities
column3: Putting the right finance and insurance in place can make a difference to all exporters, helping you win contracts, fulfil orders and get paid.
column4: UK Export Finance can help you win contracts by providing attractive financing terms to your buyers. They can also support working capital loans so you can take on and fulfil orders with confidence, and make sure you get paid by offering insurance against buyer default.

column2: Understand the financial risks
column3: There's an element of risk whenever you do business overseas. However, the benefits of opening up new markets far outweigh the risks if you plan effectively.
column4: Not getting paid on time, currency fluctuations and changes in shipping rates are all potential financial pitfalls that could affect your export business. Having procedures and finance in place to see you through difficulties should be an essential part of your export planning.

column2: Understand UK Export Finance (UKEF)
column3: You can get finance and insurance for your export business from the UK government through UK Export Finance, the UK's export credit agency.
column4: UKEF offers credit insurance, working capital support and bond support to UK exporters. It also supports UK exports with financing terms for international buyers, including direct lending and buyer credit guarantees.

column2: Understand product standards and regulations
column3: Product standards and market regulations are any legislation set by governments, industry or regulatory bodies which control how your goods can be traded in a market.
column4:
It can take a lot of time and resources to fully understand the regulations you may face in different markets, and to achieve the appropriate accreditation necessary for trade. 

You can carry out basic internet research, using the websites of the appropriate regulatory bodies and tools like the UK government's Check international trade barriers service.

column2: Explore local rules in a target market
column3: All export markets have specific rules you'll need to follow if you want to sell your products in that market. It is essential you're up to date with the latest packaging and labelling rules before you start exporting.
column4: Our Check how to export goods service can help you find the latest rules and regulations in your chosen export market. Search for your market, click on the General Information tab and scroll to the information on packaging and labelling.

column2: Understand relevant export market regulations and certifications
column3: Certification is sometimes required to prove your product or service complies with local market regulations, such as health and safety or labelling and packaging.
column4: Our Check how to export goods service can help you find the latest regulations and certifications needed to trade your goods in your chosen export market. Search for your market, click on the General Information tab and scroll to the relevant information.

column2: Understand trade and operational restrictions
column3: Trade and operational restrictions are often implemented by governments to try and offer some protection to local businesses from overseas competition. You should check for any restrictions as a priority before you start exporting your goods or services.
column4: Our Check how to export goods service can help you find trade and operational restrictions currently in place in your chosen export market. Search for your market, click on the General Information tab and scroll to the relevant information.

column2: Understand product labelling standards
column3: You cannot always rely on your UK labelling and packaging standards to be compliant in other markets, which may have different requirements. To avoid potential delays, consider what you need to do early in your export journey.
column4: Find information on regulatory requirements on the websites of each country's regulatory body. Pay attention to information like nutrition and allergy pointers and technical information such as required standards. A UK symbol, such as a kitemark, won't apply overseas, and you may need to add new symbols for your market.

column2: Identify relevant product labelling standards
column3: To make sure your product meets the right standards in your target market you need to ensure your products are labelled correctly. You should also get confirmation your legal responsibilities have been met by your legal representatives.
column4: Our Check how to export goods service can help you find the latest product labelling standards in your chosen export market. Search for your market, click on the General Information tab and scroll to the information on packaging and labelling.

column2: Categorise product or service against the UK's Strategic Export Control Regime
column3: The UK maintains a list of all items that are subject to strategic export controls. These items are controlled because of international agreements or because they relate to specific defence or security concerns.
column4: Strategic export controls apply to anyone exporting or transferring goods, software or technology, or providing brokering services. It is an exporter's responsibility to check whether items require an export licence. If a licence is required, you'll need to apply well in advance of shipment to avoid any potential issues.

column2: Understand if your product or service needs an Export Licence
column3: An export licence permits you to trade in strategically controlled goods that would otherwise be prohibited from export. Goods are controlled because of their nature and what they could be used for, or their destination market.
column4: Goods which are likely to be controlled include those which have been specially designed or modified for military use, goods that can be used for both commercial or military purposes, radioactive material and any items which fall within the remit of trade sanctions on any one country.

column2: Ensure appropriate licences are identified
column3: You must apply for a licence from the Export Control Joint Unit (ECJU) if your items are on the consolidated control list, you have concerns about the intended end-use or the end-user, or your items are covered by trade sanctions.
column4: Open General Export Licences (OGELs) are available for military and dual-use controlled items being exported to a range of destinations. For exports not covered by an OGEL, you'll need to apply for a Standard Individual Export Licence (SIEL). You can also be issued with an Open Individual Export Licence (OIEL), which is designed to cover long-term contracts, projects and repeat business.

column2: Understand specialist service qualifications, licensing and  certification
column3: To support mutual recognition of qualifications with EU and international partners, the UK government is supporting professional bodies to enter into arrangements which enable the recognition of professional qualifications overseas.
column4: A Mutal Recognition Agreement (MRA) is a formalised agreement between 2 or more parties. These agreements may provide a streamlined process by which professionals who have obtained a professional qualification in their home jurisdiction, can apply for recognition to practice in another, overseas jurisdiction.

column2: Understand UK trade sanctions
column3: Sanctions are restrictive measures put in place to fulfil a range of purposes. In the UK, these include complying with international obligations, supporting foreign policy and national security objectives, as well as maintaining international peace and security.
column4: Trade sanctions can include prohibitions on the movement of goods and technology, the provision or procurement of services related to goods and technology, and the provision or procurement of certain other non-financial services. The Export Control Joint Unit administers the UK's system of export controls and licensing in relation to trade sanctions.

column2: Understand trade embargoes and restrictions
column3: An arms embargo, for example, is a prohibition that applies to the trade or activities related to military items. An arms embargo may be imposed by the United Nations, the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe or the UK.
column4: Under the Sanctions Act, arms embargoes consist of prohibitions on export, supply or delivery, making available and transfer of military items and on the provision of technical assistance, financial services and funds, and brokering services related to military items.

column2: Apply for UK sanctions and embargo special licences
column3: DBT's Export Control Joint Unit (ECJU) has overall responsibility for trade sanctions licensing. Licence applications can be made through the online export licensing system SPIRE.
column4: You can use SPIRE to apply for open general export licences (OGELs), trade control licences (OGTCLs), standard individual export licences (SIELs), open individual export licences (OIELS) and transshipment licences.

column2: Ensure country or customer is not on the list of embargoes
column3: The UK government imposes embargoes and other trade restrictions on a number of countries, organisations and individuals. The Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO) is responsible for overall UK policy on sanctions.
column4: You can view an up-to-date list of specific countries where arms embargo, trade sanctions and other trade restrictions have been imposed. This list does not include countries subject to only financial or other types of sanctions.

column2: Understand different Incoterms
column3: Incoterms (international commercial terms) are an international shorthand system to make sure all your responsibilities, costs and associated risks of exporting products are clearly allocated, agreed and recorded.
column4: They're used worldwide, usually with a contract or other form of sales agreement for any goods you export ' and they should be recorded on your export invoices. They are produced by the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC). Incoterms 2020 has 11 terms. Seven of these cover all forms of transport and 4 are for ocean freight.

column2: Decide on shipping method
column3: You can use any combination of road, rail, air or sea to transport your goods overseas. If you're new to exporting, using a freight forwarder might be the right option.
column4: Freight forwarding is a service industry that involves moving goods around the world on behalf of exporters. It acts as an intermediary or broker between you and the shipping company, airline, rail or road haulage company. A freight forwarder may save you time and money if you're exporting large volumes of goods or high-value items.

column2: Understand how to classify your products
column3: All goods exported or imported are classified using the same system of commodity codes. It's important you know the codes for your goods so you can complete your export paperwork.
column4: The Harmonised System (HS) of commodity codes is internationally recognised and over 98% of all international trade uses the system. Each unique code allows customs officials to identify the goods being traded and ensure the correct duties and tariffs are paid.  Classifying your goods incorrectly can lead to delays in transit and additional costs to your business.

column2: Apply for an Advance Tariff Ruling
column3: An Advance Tariff Ruling is a legally binding decision on the classification of your goods. This means your choice of commodity code has been verified and approved by customs officials.
column4: These rulings are particularly useful if you have goods that are difficult to classify and can give you peace of mind that your duties and tariffs are calculated correctly. You can apply online, but you must do this before all customs procedures have been completed and cannot apply retrospectively.

column2: Understand tax and duty liabilities
column3: Duties are a levy charged on goods entering a country, designed to protect local industries. Sales tax or VAT is a national charge in your export market, placed on most purchased products.
column4: Generally, duties and taxes aren't paid by exporters. However, they will always impact the amount you charge your buyers and the price of your goods in the market. So, it's crucial you're clear on how much these charges are and that you're on top of any paperwork.

column2: Calculate rate of tax and duty in your destination country'
column3: Calculating the amount of tax and duty levied on your exported goods is an essential part of your pricing strategy. The rate is determined by your product, its country of manufacture and any trade agreements that might be in place.
column4: To find the rates of tax and duty for your product you can use our Check how to export goods service. Choose your destination country, find your product using the commodity code lookup and see all relevant taxes and duties. You can then calculate the costs for your complete consignment.

column2: Understand withholding taxes when exporting services
column3: Withholding tax is sometimes levied on income from service exports by overseas governments. If a withholding tax policy is in place, your overseas client will retain a percentage of the money owed and pay it directly to the local government.
column4: Withholding tax is sometimes levied on income from service exports by overseas governments. If a withholding tax policy is in place, your overseas client will retain a percentage of the money owed and pay it directly to the local government.

column2: Understand rules of origin
column3: Rules of origin (ROO) determine the economic nationality of goods. They're used to judge how much of that product originated from a specific nation, and how much value was added to it during the manufacturing process.
column4: The country of origin of a product can dictate how much duty is paid on it, and sometimes whether it can be exported to a particular country at all. By using ROO to accurately detail your product's origins, you could enable your importer to pay a lower tariff. For this to happen, you'll need to demonstrate to the customs authority that you've met certain ROO requirements, as laid out in trade agreements.

column2: Understand how to determine the country of origin of your goods
column3: The country of origin of a product is usually the country where it was manufactured, produced or grown. Understanding the country of origin of your goods can reduce the amount of duty importers need to pay.
column4: Where 2 or more countries are involved in the manufacture of goods, the country of origin is where the last substantial manufacturing or processing has been performed. In this instance, 'substantial' is deemed as giving a commodity its essential character.

column2: Complete the necessary certificates of origin
column3: The paperwork you need to prove the origin of your goods depends on the country you're exporting to, and whether the UK has a trade agreement in place with that country.
column4: You can use our Tariff Checker service to check which of the different types of proof of origin you need. Types of certificates include EUR-MED movement certificate, an origin declaration, or importers knowledge. The length of time a proof of origin will be valid depends on the agreement and the type of proof.

column2: Apply for a Binding Origin decision
column3: A binding or advance origin ruling is a legally binding document that certifies the economic origin of the goods you're exporting. It gives you protection against any UK customs authority challenging the country of origin of your product.
column4: Any exporter with an EORI number exporting from the UK can apply, but all applications must be made before all customs procedures have been completed. Applications can be done online, and you should receive a decision within 120 days.

column2: Understand what a service export is
column3: Any UK service business that operates in another country is a service exporter. The UK's financial, creative and IT sectors are big service exporters, along with education, travel and tourism.
column4: Although service exporters don't have the same challenges as moving physical goods across borders, there are many things to think about when preparing your business to operate in another country. This includes tax implications, cultural differences and hiring personnel.

column2: Understand VAT and taxation rules in the destination country
column3: Understanding where you may need to pay VAT when exporting services is an important part of your export planning. Place of supply rules will determine whether you pay VAT in the UK or in the country of supply.
column4:
Working out the place of supply for a service can often be complicated and there are various rules to consider. 

For most service providers, the place of supply is decided by what's known as the 'general rule'. But some supplies are subject to special rules that will affect their place of supply.

column2: UK VAT considerations for service providers
column3: All UK VAT registered businesses must charge VAT on the goods and services they sell unless they are exempt. Depending on place of supply rules, you may be able to charge zero rate on the services you export.
column4:
If you're in the UK and the place of supply of your service is in the UK, you charge and account for VAT according to UK VAT rules. 

If you're in the UK and the place of supply of your service is in an EU country, you do not pay UK VAT. If the place of supply of your service is not in the EU, you do not have to charge EU VAT but you should include the sale on your VAT Return.

column2: Check if you need to make a customs declaration
column3: A customs declaration is a legal document that helps governments track the movement of goods across the world, making sure that the correct duties are paid, and shipments are safe and legal.
column4: To export goods from the UK to any country, including the EU, you need to make a customs declaration. It's essential you provide accurate information about your business and your shipment. For smaller businesses, it's often simpler to pay someone to look after this process, such as freight forwarders, customs agents or international couriers.

column2: Get the right commodity code
column3: The Harmonised System (HS) of commodity codes is internationally recognised. Each unique code allows customs officials to identify the goods being traded and ensure the correct duties and tariffs are paid.
column4:
Although many countries have signed up to the same classification system, only the first 6 digits are used worldwide, with product-specific decisions particular to each country. 

If you rely on the commodity code from an overseas supplier, you'll need to check if the treatment is the same and how much of the code applies in the UK.

column2: Understand the different types of declarations
column3: There are several ways you can make an export declaration. The most common are a full declaration or a simplified declaration, both of which can be made electronically.
column4: There are some variations on these 2 declaration types which can be made under certain conditions. You may also be able to make an oral declaration by conduct, depending on your circumstances.

column2: Make a full declaration
column3: You can use this online service to make or manage a declaration of goods being exported from Great Britain to a country outside the UK.
column4: You'll need the Government Gateway user ID and password linked to your EORI number. If you do not have a Government Gateway user ID you can create one the first time you make a declaration.

column2: Make a simplified declaration
column3: You can use this online service to make or manage a declaration of goods being exported from Great Britain to a country outside the UK.
column4: You'll need the Government Gateway user ID and password linked to your EORI number. If you do not have a Government Gateway user ID you can create one the first time you make a declaration.

column2: Make an oral declaration
column3: An oral declaration can be made by passing through a red channel at a port or airport, and verbally telling a customs officer what the goods are, what the purpose of the goods is and who you're making this declaration for.
column4:
If you're travelling on a ferry crossing, the ferry operator may ask you to confirm that you do not need a goods movement reference. 

If you are eligible to make your declaration orally, you will not need a goods movement reference for your journey. You may be asked to confirm this by agreeing with a written statement.

column2: Declaration by conduct
column3: A declaration by conduct is when you transport your goods through a customs control point (usually a green channel marked 'nothing to declare') at a port or airport.
column4: You can declare goods you bring into the UK by conduct, if they are below your personal allowance limit and are for your own use or intended to be given as a gift. You do not need to stop or speak to a customs officer, you can simply walk or drive through a customs control point with the goods.

column2: Submit your declarations
column3: You can use this online service to make or manage a declaration of goods being exported from Great Britain to a country outside the UK.
column4: You'll need the Government Gateway user ID and password linked to your EORI number. If you do not have a Government Gateway user ID you can create one the first time you make a declaration.

column2: Shipping with Royal Mail
column3: Royal mail can ship to over 230 countries and territories with their worldwide network of delivery partners.
column4:
Use Royal Mail's country guides to find the information you need to send parcels and mail around the world. Check what you're allowed to send with prohibited and restricted item guides and learn the best way to write the address for your destination. 

You can choose from a range of services based on price, security or speed.

column2: Merchandise in baggage
column3: Merchandise in baggage are commercial goods you plan to sell and export by taking them in your baggage or in a small vehicle. As with all commercial goods, you must declare them in the usual way.
column4: To qualify for merchandise in baggage, the commercial goods must not be carried by a commercial transport operator. They must be transported in your baggage, or they are transported in a vehicle that can carry no more than 9 people and is 3.5 tonnes or less.

column2: Zero rating goods for export
column3: If you export goods from the UK, you don't normally need to charge VAT. You can zero rate most exports from Great Britain to outside the UK, or from Northern Ireland to outside the UK and EU.
column4: You can zero rate the sale if you get and keep evidence of the export, while complying with all other conditions. You must also make sure the goods are exported, and you must get the evidence within 3 months from the time of sale.

column2: VAT on services exports
column3: All UK VAT registered businesses must charge VAT on the goods and services they sell unless they are exempt. Depending on place of supply rules, you may be able to charge zero rate on the services you export.
column4:
If you're in the UK and the place of supply of your service is in the UK, you charge and account for VAT according to UK VAT rules. 

If you're in the UK and the place of supply of your service is in an EU country, you do not pay UK VAT. If the place of supply of your service is not in the EU, you do not have to charge EU VAT but you should include the sale on your VAT Return.

column2: Understand how to hire someone to conduct declarations on your behalf
column3: You can hire a person or business to deal with customs for you. Before appointing someone there are several things to consider, including your business needs and how you will be charged.
column4: There are different types of people or businesses who can help you, such as freight forwarders, customs agents or brokers and fast parcel operators. All of these will need to be established in the UK for customs. You'll need to confirm in writing the terms and conditions of your representation and keep a copy of this agreement for your own records.

column2: Find a customs agent or fast parcel operator
column3: It can be complicated to submit export declarations, so you may want to use a company which specialises in this area. You can use our register to find someone to help you with your customs paperwork.
column4:
Customs agents on this list provide a range of customs services on traders' behalf. 

Fast parcel operators on this list offer a range of customs services for both low and high-value parcels.

column2: Learn about freight forwarding: moving goods
column3: Freight forwarders specialise in moving cargo, arranging customs clearance, maintaining all documentation, overseeing cargo packing and dealing with the movement of dangerous goods.
column4: One of a freight forwarder's main functions is to arrange customs clearance of goods crossing a border. Freight forwarders can do this themselves or subcontract it to a company that specialises in customs broking. They also need specific software that can communicate with the HMRC central computer.

column2: Register for the Goods Vehicle Movement Service (GVMS)
column3: The Goods Vehicle Movement Service brings together multiple declaration reference numbers into a single goods movement reference. This speeds up the clearance of goods through customs.
column4: You cannot move goods through ports using the GVMS without a goods movement reference. You need to register for the GVMS if you export goods from the UK, through a port which uses the GVMS.

column2: Using transit to move goods out of, into and through the UK
column3: Transit is a customs procedure that can help you move goods between the UK and other Common Transit Convention countries. It can help you move your goods quickly and reduce the number of declarations you'll need.
column4: When moving goods under transit you can delay completing customs declarations on goods until they end their transit movement. You can also delay paying customs duties and other charges on the goods until they end their transit movement.

column2: Understand how to take goods temporarily out of the UK
column3: You might be able to claim relief from duty and declare goods in an easier way if you're exporting them temporarily ' for example, for a trade show or event.
column4: Depending on what the goods are, you might be able to use a simpler type of declaration, such as a declaration by conduct or by using an ATA Carnet. When the goods are re-imported you can also claim Returned goods relief (RGR) on any duty you may have paid.

column2: Apply for an ATA Carnet
column3: ATA Carnet lets you temporarily export commercial samples, exhibition goods and professional equipment. It's a document that works like a passport for goods and is used by many countries worldwide.
column4:
Using the ATA Carnet means you'll not pay customs charges. It simplifies clearing your goods through customs, gives financial security for customs charges that could be due, and removes the need for a customs declaration.  

Types of goods and uses vary between participating countries. The association in the issuing country will tell you if you can use a carnet in the countries you visit.

column2: Claim with a Duplicate List
column3: You can use a Duplicate List to temporarily export goods from Great Britain and to not pay duty when you bring those goods back into Great Britain.
column4: The Duplicate List can be used in place of export or import declarations when leaving and re-entering Great Britain. You'll usually need to make a customs declaration and pay duty in any other countries you are entering. You must ensure you can get your Duplicate List stamped before departure.

column2: Claim with Returned Goods Relief (RGR)
column3: You can get relief from customs duty if you're re-importing goods into the UK that have previously been exported or transported from the UK. This is known as Returned Goods Relief.
column4: To claim Returned Goods Relief, the exporter and importer must be the same person. The goods must be re-imported in an unaltered state, apart from any work that may have been carried out to maintain the goods in working order, the goods cannot have been upgraded to increase their value.

column2: Understand if you can use a customs special procedure
column3: Customs special procedures allow you to store, temporarily use, process or repair your goods and get partial or full relief from import duty, or in some cases suspension.
column4: Processing can be anything from simply sorting or repacking goods, up to the most complicated manufacturing. Repair is when goods are restored to their original working condition, but do not improve their performance. If you want to claim relief on goods for repair, you need to expect the goods to be repairable.

column2: Using inward processing to process or repair your goods
column3: Inward processing allows goods to be imported into the UK for processing without paying any duty or tax. For example, if the goods are being repaired or altered.
column4:
You can temporarily export your goods outside the UK for further processing. The time the goods spend outside the UK counts towards the total time they can stay in the procedure. 

If you need to temporarily export inward processing goods outside the UK for further process and return, this must be done under a full outward processing authorisation.

column2: Using outward processing to process or repair your goods
column3: Outward processing means you can temporarily export goods to another country for processing and then re-import them with a partial or total relief from import duty.
column4: You can apply for an outward processing authorisation if you are established in the UK. You do not have to own the goods that are exported, and you do not have to be the person re-importing them. Another person can do that if they have your permission.

column2: Apply for Temporary Admission to import goods to or from the UK
column3: A Temporary Admission allows you to import goods to the UK, or move goods from Great Britain to Northern Ireland, and use them temporarily before re-exporting them.
column4: You can apply for a Temporary Admission if you're the person using the goods or arranging an import declaration for the goods to be used on your behalf. Using Temporary Admission in Great Britain will depend on if you're established inside or outside the UK. In Northern Ireland, it will depend on if you're established inside or outside the EU.

column2: Eligible goods and authorised uses
column3: You can only use customs special procedures if the goods you are moving are authorised for a specific use.
column4: The UK Government keeps an updated list of all commodity codes of goods that are eligible for an Authorised Use suspension. You need to make a declaration when you place your goods into authorised use and include your authorisation number.

column2: Do I need a visa or work permit?
column3: Most countries have strict immigration requirements which means you'll need a visa, work permit or other documentation if you want to work in that country, even if it's only for a short time.
column4: The Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO) has information about the visa and work permit requirements for over 220 countries. Find the country or overseas territory you want to travel to and follow the links for the local entry requirements.

column2: Check individual market entry requirements
column3: The Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO) has information about the visa and work permit requirements for over 220 countries.
column4: Find the country or overseas territory you want to travel to and find information on entry requirements, as well as general advice and warnings about travelling abroad.

column2: Check foreign travel advice for up to date travel information
column3: The Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO) has information about the visa and work permit requirements for over 220 countries.
column4: Find the country or overseas territory you want to travel to and find information on entry requirements, as well as general advice and warnings about travelling abroad.

column2: Consult with overseas official authorities
column3: In certain circumstances, you may need to get in touch with the authorities of the country you want to visit before you leave.
column4: Most countries and overseas territories have a consular presence in the UK. The London Diplomatic List contains the addresses and contact details of all embassies and high commissions in London and around the UK.

column2: Speak to an immigration lawyer
column3: Sometimes it might be necessary to talk to a specialist immigration lawyer before you submit your visa or work permit applications.
column4: It is advised that you get advice and information as early as you can. You can find an immigration lawyer near you by using the Law Society websites.

column2: Understand how to temporarily take goods overseas for work
column3: You might be able to claim relief from duty and declare goods in an easier way if you're exporting them temporarily ' for example, for a trade show or event.
column4: Depending on what the goods are, you might be able to use a simpler type of declaration, such as a declaration by conduct or by using an ATA Carnet. When the goods are re-imported you can also claim Returned Goods Relief (RGR) on any duty you may have paid.

column2: Understand how to take goods in hand luggage
column3: You are allowed to export goods by taking them in your hand luggage, also known as merchandise in baggage, but you must declare them in the same way as other exported goods.
column4: Depending on the goods you are exporting in your luggage, you may need to make a full declaration, a simple online declaration or a declaration by conduct. You should check the customs requirements for the country you're travelling to because these may differ from UK requirements.

column2: Apply for social security and income tax certification (A1)
column3: If you leave the UK to work in the EU, Gibraltar, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway or Switzerland, you will only pay into one country's social security scheme at a time.
column4: You will usually pay social security contributions (National Insurance in the UK) in the country you are working in. The HMRC can confirm that you or your employees pay only UK National Insurance contributions whilst working temporarily in EU, Gibraltar, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway or Switzerland.

column2: Returning goods to the UK
column3: To return goods to the UK, there are differing requirements depending on if the goods were previously in free circulation in the UK or the EU before being returned or were rejected at the border of the country you exported them to.
column4: You may be able to claim Returns Goods Relief (RGR) on goods you re-import into the UK. The goods must be re-imported in an unaltered state, apart from any work that may have been carried out to maintain the goods in working order, and the goods cannot have been upgraded to increase their value.

column2: Get import duty reflief under Returned Goods Relief (RGR)
column3: You can get relief from customs duty if you're re-importing goods into the UK that have previously been exported or transported from the UK. This is known as Returned Goods Relief.
column4: To claim Returned Goods Relief, the exporter and importer must be the same person. The goods must be re-imported in an unaltered state, apart from any work that may have been carried out to maintain the goods in working order, the goods cannot have been upgraded to increase their value.

column2: Find a specialist lawyer
column3: The Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO) provides lists of English-speaking lawyers abroad to help British nationals find the legal support they need.
column4: You can find lawyers by country or a more specific location, and search for legal support within a particular area of expertise or practice. All lawyers on the lists have confirmed they can provide services in English.

column2: Identify and mitigate risk
column3: Exporting always comes with an element of risk. Your business integrity, intellectual property and data all need to be protected and managed as you enter a new export market.
column4: The first step is to conduct thorough research on your target export market. Once you've understood the risks that are present in that market, you can work out how to manage them and include any mitigation measures in your export plan.

column2: How to insure against non-paymnt when exporting
column3: Trade credit insurance moves the risk of non-payment from your company to the insurer. It can protect you from the non-payment, insolvency or bankruptcy of your customers.
column4: The UK government organisation, UK Export Finance (UKEF), works with banks and insurers to arrange insurance policies for exporters. Its advisers have a wide knowledge of the insurance options available to UK exporters and how they work.

column2: Ensure exports are properly valued and insured
column3: UK Export Finance (UKEF), the government's export credit agency, can insure you for up to 95% of potential losses, under an export contract.
column4: Cover includes if a buyer fails to pay, if a contract is terminated before shipment and if your export cannot be completed due to political events. UKEF export insurance covers most types of business and sectors, as long as you have the relevant export licences, if they are required.

column2: Understand what to include in a contract
column3: It's important to draft a contract as soon as you've found a potential buyer for your product to make sure you have complete clarity on everything you agree.
column4: A contract is a specific type of agreement that, by its terms and elements, is legally binding and enforceable in a court of law. Every contract will be different and dependent on what you agree with the buyer. But there are certain elements you should always include.

column2: Understand international exporting terminology
column3: Understanding the terminology of exporting can be difficult when you're starting out as an exporter. But it's important you familiarise yourself with the language before you start any negotiations or paperwork.
column4: We have a glossary of common terms used when completing export documentation and contracts. If you're new to exporting you should consider using intermediaries, such as a freight forwarder, to help you complete any documentation correctly.

column2: Get help negotiating a sale
column3: You may need to negotiate on price when pitching for new business, especially if you're selling your product through distribution partners, or as part of a tender process.
column4: How long this takes depends on many factors, such as the complexity of your market, volume of sales and how negotiations are handled culturally. If you're negotiating the price of a single product through a distribution partner, it might be easy to agree. Whereas tendering for a large government contract may be a much longer process.

column2: Understand the legal advice that's available
column3: It maybe necessary for you to seek legal advice to ensure your exports comply with the law in the UK and overseas. Getting the right help will give you the time and space to concentrate on building your overseas business.
column4: The type of advice will depend on your particular situation. The Law Society can help you find legal advice in your local area or across the UK and can provide you with the contact details of lawyers who specialise in trade and exports.

column2: Understand how to manage international payment disputes
column3: Managing payments is an important part of trading successfully. It is vital that businesses manage this process just as carefully as they would when dealing with domestic clients.
column4: Once a payment is late or missed, follow up immediately. Try to establish the cause of non-payment and seek to resolve it as a matter of urgency. If the reason for non-payment is financial, consider whether a short extension of payment terms will help to resolve the situation.

column2: Find a lawyer
column3: The Law Society can help you find legal advice in your local area or across the UK and can provide you with the contact details of lawyers who specialise in trade and exports.
column4: The right lawyer could help you prepare the legal documents you may need for your exports and help to resolve any disputes or disagreements you are experiencing with your overseas customers.
